articles.title: Six-hour ‘undo’ button: GAI-17 rewinds stroke damage and may beat Alzheimer’s
articles.summary: Stroke kills millions, but Osaka researchers have unveiled GAI-17, a drug that halts toxic GAPDH clumping, slashes brain damage and paralysis in mice—even when given six hours post-stroke—and shows no major side effects, hinting at a single therapy that could also tackle Alzheimer’s and other tough neurological disorders.
articles.content:
Stroke is said to be the second leading cause of death worldwide after heart disease. To prevent the death of neurons in the brain, a research group led by Osaka Metropolitan University Associate Professor Hidemitsu Nakajima of the Graduate School of Veterinary Science has developed a drug that inhibits a protein involved in cell death.

The multifunctional protein GAPDH (glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase) is linked to pathogenesis in many intractable brain and nervous system diseases. The team developed GAI-17, a GAPDH aggregation inhibitor. When this inhibitor was administered to model mice with acute strokes, there was a significantly lower level of brain cell death and paralysis compared to untreated mice.

GAI-17 also showed no side effects of concern, such as adverse effects on the heart or cerebrovascular system. Furthermore, experiments using GAI-17 showed improvement in the mice even when administered six hours after a stroke.

"The GAPDH aggregation inhibitor we have developed is expected to be a single drug that can treat many intractable neurological diseases, including Alzheimer's disease," stated Professor Nakajima. "Going forward, we will verify the effectiveness of this approach in disease models other than stroke and promote further practical research toward the realization of a healthy and long-lived society."

The findings were published in iScience.
articles.reasoning: This article reports a significant medical breakthrough with the development of GAI-17, a drug that reduces brain damage from strokes and shows promise for treating Alzheimer's and other neurological diseases. The drug's effectiveness even when administered six hours post-stroke and the absence of major side effects make it highly hopeful for future treatments, potentially improving millions of lives worldwide.
articles.personality_title: New drug offers hope by reversing stroke damage hours after onset
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Stroke is one of the leading causes of death and disability worldwide, often leaving survivors with lasting brain damage and paralysis. Scientists have been searching for treatments that can protect the brain even hours after a stroke happens.

**What happened**
Researchers at Osaka Metropolitan University have developed a drug called GAI-17 that targets a protein responsible for cell death in the brain. In studies with mice, GAI-17 was able to reduce brain damage and paralysis caused by strokes, even when given six hours after the stroke occurred. Remarkably, the drug showed no major side effects.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means there could soon be a treatment that not only saves lives but also improves recovery by stopping harmful processes in the brain well after a stroke begins. Additionally, because the drug affects a protein involved in other brain diseases, it might help treat Alzheimer's and other tough neurological conditions too.

**What's next step**
The research team plans to continue testing GAI-17 to confirm its safety and effectiveness in humans. If successful, this could lead to a new, widely available therapy that changes how strokes and brain diseases are treated.

**One-sentence takeaway**
GAI-17 offers a promising new way to reverse stroke damage hours after it happens and could one day help fight Alzheimer's and other brain disorders.

articles.title: Dogs can detect Parkinson’s years before symptoms—with 98% accuracy
articles.summary: Dogs trained to detect Parkinson’s disease using scent have shown remarkable accuracy in new research. In a double-blind trial, they identified skin swabs from people with Parkinson’s with up to 80% sensitivity and 98% specificity, even when other health conditions were present. The findings offer hope for a simple, non-invasive diagnostic method using biomarkers that appear long before traditional symptoms, potentially allowing earlier treatment and slowed disease progression.
articles.content:
People with Parkinson's disease (PD) have an odour that can be reliably detected from skin swabs by trained dogs, a new study has shown.

The research, in collaboration with Medical Detection Dogs and the Universities of Bristol and Manchester, was published on July 15 in The Journal of Parkinson's Disease.

Two dogs were trained by the charity, Medical Detection Dogs, to distinguish between sebum swabs from people with and without Parkinson's disease.

In a double blind trial, they showed sensitivity of up to 80% and specificity of up to 98%.

Not only that, they detected it in samples from patients who also had other health conditions.

The dogs were trained over a number of weeks on over 200 odor samples from individuals that had tested positive for PD and control samples from people who did not have the disease. Samples were presented to the dogs on a stand system and the dogs were rewarded for correctly indicating a positive sample and for correctly ignoring a negative sample.

In the double-blind testing, meaning that only a computer knew where the correct samples were, each line was also presented in reverse order so that samples for which no decision was made were re-presented. Then any unsearched samples were collected together in new lines, until a decision had been made for all samples.

A definitive diagnostic test for Parkinson's Disease (PD) remains elusive, so identification of potential biomarkers could help diagnosis and timely intervention.

Claire Guest, Medical Detection Dogs CEO and Chief Scientific Officer, says: "We are extremely proud to say that once again, dogs can very accurately detect disease.

"There is currently no early test for Parkinson's disease and symptoms may start up to 20 years before they become visible and persistent leading to a confirmed diagnosis.

"Timely diagnosis is key as subsequent treatment could slow down the progression of the disease and reduce the intensity of symptoms."

Nicola Rooney, Associate Professor at Bristol Veterinary School at the University of Bristol and lead author, says: "Identifying diagnostic biomarkers of PD, particularly those that may predict development or help diagnose disease earlier is the subject of much ongoing research. The dogs in this study achieved high sensitivity and specificity and showed there is an olfactory signature distinct to patients with the disease. Sensitivity levels of 70% and 80% are well above chance and I believe that dogs could help us to develop a quick non-invasive and cost-effective method to identify patients with Parkinson's disease."

Perdita Barran, Professor of Mass Spectrometry at The University of Manchester, said: "It's wonderful to be part of this research inspired by Joy Milne and our Nose2Diagnose programme. This study adds to the growing body of evidence showing that simple, non-invasive skin swabs can be used to diagnose Parkinson's disease, offering a faster and more accessible method for early detection."

The two dogs in the study were Golden Retriever, Bumper and Black Labrador, Peanut.
articles.reasoning: This article reports a significant medical breakthrough where trained dogs can detect Parkinson’s disease with high accuracy years before symptoms appear, offering hope for earlier diagnosis and treatment that could slow disease progression.
articles.personality_title: Dogs sniff out Parkinson’s years before symptoms with remarkable accuracy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long searched for ways to detect Parkinson’s disease early, before symptoms become obvious. Early diagnosis is key to starting treatment sooner and improving quality of life. Now, a surprising helper has joined the fight: dogs.

**What happened**
In a recent study, two specially trained dogs were able to identify Parkinson’s disease by smelling skin swabs from people. These dogs could tell the difference between samples from those with Parkinson’s and those without, even when other health issues were present. Their accuracy was impressive — they correctly identified the disease with up to 80% sensitivity and 98% specificity in a careful, double-blind trial.

**Impact**
This breakthrough means a simple, non-invasive method could be developed to detect Parkinson’s disease much earlier than current techniques allow. Detecting the disease years before symptoms appear opens the door to earlier treatment that might slow down the progression and improve lives.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to expand the study with more dogs and more participants to confirm these findings. They also aim to understand exactly what scent markers the dogs are detecting. This could lead to new diagnostic tools inspired by the dogs’ incredible noses.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Trained dogs can detect Parkinson’s disease years before symptoms show, offering hope for earlier diagnosis and better treatment.

articles.title: New study cracks the “tissue code” — just five rules shape organs
articles.summary: Scientists have uncovered a surprisingly simple “tissue code”: five rules that choreograph when, where, and how cells divide, move, and die, allowing organs like the colon to remain flawlessly organized even as they renew every few days. Mathematical models showed that manipulating just these parameters faithfully recreates real tissue architecture, hinting that the same code may govern skin, brain, and more. The discovery offers a fresh way to understand healing, birth defects, and cancer, and could supercharge initiatives such as the Human Cell Atlas by turning static cell maps into dynamic predictions.
articles.content:
Every day, your body replaces billions of cells -- and yet, your tissues stay perfectly organized. How is that possible?

A team of researchers at ChristianaCare's Helen F. Graham Cancer Center & Research Institute and the University of Delaware believe they've found an answer. In a new study published in the scientific journal Biology of the Cell, they show that just five basic rules may explain how the body maintains the complex structure of tissues like those in the colon, for example, even as its cells are constantly dying and being replaced.

This research is the product of more than 15 years of collaboration between mathematicians and cancer biologists to unlock the rules that govern tissue structure and cellular behavior.

"This may be the biological version of a blueprint," said Bruce Boman, M.D., Ph.D., senior research scientist at ChristianaCare's Cawley Center for Translational Cancer Research and faculty member in the departments of Biological Sciences and Mathematical Sciences at the University of Delaware. "Just like we have a genetic code that explains how our genes work, we may also have a 'tissue code' that explains how our bodies stay so precisely organized over time."

Math Meets Medicine

The researchers used mathematical modeling -- essentially, creating a computer simulation of how cells behave -- to see if a small number of rules could account for the highly organized structure of the lining of the colon. That's an ideal place to study: cells in the colon renew every few days, but the overall shape and structure stays remarkably stable.

After running many simulations and refining their models, the team identified five core biological rules that appear to govern the structure and behavior of cells:

Timing of cell division. The order in which cells divide. The direction cells divide and move. How many times cells divide. How long a cell lives before it dies.

"These rules work together like choreography," said Gilberto Schleiniger, Ph.D., professor in the University of Delaware's Department of Mathematical Sciences. "They control where cells go, when they divide and how long they stick around -- and that's what keeps tissues looking and working the way they should."

Decoding Human Tissue

The researchers believe these rules may apply not just to the colon, but to many different tissues throughout the body -- skin, liver, brain and beyond. If true, this "tissue code" could help scientists better understand how tissues heal after injury, how birth defects happen and how diseases like cancer develop when that code gets disrupted.

Boman explained it this way: "Your tissues don't just grow and shrink randomly. They know what they're supposed to look like, and they know how to get back to that state, even after damage. That level of precision needs a set of instructions. What we've found is a strong candidate for those instructions."

This work also has important implications for the Human Cell Atlas, a global scientific collaboration working to map every cell type in the human body. While the Atlas aims to catalog what each cell is and what it's doing at a given moment, this new research offers a dynamic framework for understanding how those cells stay organized over time. By identifying simple, universal rules that govern cell behavior and tissue structure, the findings could help guide future efforts to not only describe cells, but predict how they behave in health and disease.

Implications for Disease and Discovery

One reason the team turned to mathematical models, rather than traditional biology experiments, is that it's extremely difficult to observe how every single cell in a tissue behaves in real time. But with computer models, researchers can run simulations that reveal patterns and dynamics hidden from view.

This kind of collaboration between biology and math reflects a broader shift in how scientists approach complex problems. It also aligns with national priorities: the National Science Foundation's "Rules of Life" initiative challenges researchers to uncover the fundamental principles that govern living systems. This study is a strong step in that direction.

Next steps for the team include testing the model's predictions experimentally, refining it with additional data and exploring its relevance to cancer biology -- especially how disruptions to the tissue code may lead to tumor growth or metastasis.

"This is just the beginning," said Schleiniger. "Once you can identify the rules, you can begin to ask entirely new questions, and maybe even learn how to fix what's gone wrong."

Funding for this project was provided by the National Institutes of Health, the National Science Foundation, The Lisa Dean Moseley Foundation, the Delaware Bioscience Center for Advanced Technology (CAT) and the UNIDEL Graduate Research Fellowship.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding how tissues maintain their structure and function, which has promising implications for healing, birth defects, and cancer research. This advancement offers hope for improved medical treatments and a deeper understanding of human biology.
articles.personality_title: Scientists discover simple code behind how our organs stay organized
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Our bodies are constantly renewing, replacing billions of cells every day. Yet, organs like the colon remain perfectly organized despite this nonstop change. Understanding how this happens has puzzled scientists for years.

**What happened**
A team of researchers from ChristianaCare and the University of Delaware uncovered a simple “tissue code” made up of just five important rules. These rules control when, where, and how cells divide, move, and die. By using mathematical models, the scientists showed that following these five rules can recreate the complex structure of real tissues.

**Impact**
This discovery could change how we understand healing, birth defects, and diseases like cancer. It also offers a new tool to improve projects like the Human Cell Atlas, helping scientists predict how tissues change over time instead of just mapping them at one moment.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to explore if this five-rule code applies to other organs, like skin and brain, and how it might be used to develop better treatments for tissue damage and disease.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A simple set of five rules governs how our organs stay beautifully organized, opening new doors for medicine and biology.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques découvrent un code simple derrière la façon dont nos organes restent organisés
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Nos corps se renouvellent constamment, remplaçant des milliards de cellules chaque jour. Pourtant, des organes comme le côlon restent parfaitement organisés malgré ce changement sans arrêt. Comprendre comment cela se produit a intrigué les scientifiques depuis des années.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Une équipe de chercheurs de Christianacare et de l'Université du Delaware a révélé un simple «code tissulaire» composé de seulement cinq règles importantes. Ces règles contrôlent quand, où et comment les cellules divisent, se déplacent et meurent. En utilisant des modèles mathématiques, les scientifiques ont montré que la suite de ces cinq règles peut recréer la structure complexe des tissus réels.

**Impact**
Cette découverte pourrait changer la façon dont nous comprenons la guérison, les malformations congénitales et les maladies comme le cancer. Il propose également un nouvel outil pour améliorer des projets comme l'atlas de cellules humaines, aidant les scientifiques à prédire comment les tissus changent avec le temps au lieu de simplement les cartographier à un moment.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient d'explorer si ce code à cinq règles s'applique à d'autres organes, comme la peau et le cerveau, et comment il pourrait être utilisé pour développer de meilleurs traitements pour les lésions tissulaires et les maladies.

Un ensemble simple de cinq règles régit la façon dont nos organes restent magnifiquement organisés, ouvrant de nouvelles portes pour la médecine et la biologie.
articles.personality_title_es: Los científicos descubren un código simple detrás de cómo nuestros órganos se mantienen organizados
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Nuestros cuerpos renovan constantemente, reemplazando a miles de millones de células todos los días. Sin embargo, los órganos como el colon permanecen perfectamente organizados a pesar de este cambio sin parar. Comprender cómo sucede esto ha desconcertado a los científicos durante años.

articles.title: 1,000-year-old health hacks are trending—and backed by science
articles.summary: Medieval medicine is undergoing a reputation makeover. New research reveals that far from being stuck in superstition, early Europeans actively explored healing practices based on nature, observation, and practical experience—some of which uncannily echo today’s wellness trends on TikTok.
articles.content:
It turns out the Dark Ages weren't all that dark! According to new research, medieval medicine was way more sophisticated than previously thought, and some of its remedies are trending today on TikTok.

A new international research project featuring faculty at Binghamton University, State University of New York reveals that people in the Middle Ages weren't cooped up in castles, wallowing in superstition. They were developing health practices based on the best knowledge they had at the time - some of which mirror modern wellness trends.

"People were engaging with medicine on a much broader scale than had previously been thought," said Meg Leja, an associate professor of history at Binghamton University who specializes in the political and cultural history of late antique and medieval Europe. "They were concerned about cures, they wanted to observe the natural world and jot down bits of information wherever they could in this period known as the 'Dark Ages.'"

The Corpus of Early Medieval Latin Medicine (CEMLM), funded by the British Academy, has collected hundreds of medieval manuscripts containing medical material predating the 11th century. Countless manuscripts that have been left out of previous catalogs were included, nearly doubling the number of known medical manuscripts from the Dark Ages.

Some of the recipes resemble health hacks promoted by modern-day influencers, from topical ointments to detox cleanses. Have a headache? Crush the stone of a peach, mix it with rose oil and smear it on your forehead. It might sound odd, but one study published in 2017 showed that rose oil may actually help alleviate migraine pain.

Then there's lizard shampoo, where you take pieces of lizard to help your hair become more luscious and flowing - or even to remove it, a modern-day parallel to waxing.

"A lot of things that you see in these manuscripts are actually being promoted online currently as alternative medicine, but they have been around for thousands of years," said Leja.

Leja spent the last two years with the rest of the team preparing the new catalogue (which was just released online), reviewing manuscripts from throughout Europe, and editing and formatting the catalog. She had previously written about medieval medicine in her first book, Embodying the Soul: Medicine and Religion in Carolingian Europe.

Many of the writings were found within the margins of books totally unrelated to medicine -- manuscripts on grammar, theology, poetry , etc. Leja said that this speaks to a preoccupation with the body's health and figuring out ways to control it.

"It's true that we do lack a lot of sources for the period. In that sense, it is 'dark.' But not in terms of any kind of 'anti-science' attitudes -- people in the early Middle Ages were quite into science, into observation, into figuring out the utility of different natural substances, and trying to identify patterns and make predictions" said Leja.

The research team will continue to update the catalog with new manuscripts and are working on new editions and translations of medical texts that could be used in teaching. Leja noted that while previously catalogs focused on texts from well-known authorities like Hippocrates, this isn't necessarily material that people in the Dark Ages would have prioritized, and a more comprehensive catalog will allow historians to show medicine in its fullness.

The Corpus of Early Medieval Latin Medicine (CEMLM) is available online, produced by team members from Binghamton, Fordham, St. Andrews, Utrecht, and Oslo.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a positive scientific discovery about medieval medicine, showing early Europeans' sophisticated health practices that align with modern wellness trends. It promotes a hopeful view of historical science and ongoing research that could enrich medical knowledge and education.
articles.personality_title: Medieval health tips make a comeback with a modern twist
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
New research is shining a fresh light on medieval medicine, showing that early Europeans weren’t just relying on superstition. Instead, they used nature, careful observation, and hands-on experience to develop health remedies, some of which surprisingly match today’s popular wellness tips.

**What happened**
An international team, including experts from Binghamton University, discovered that medieval health practices were more thoughtful and advanced than we used to believe. These ancient remedies, once overlooked, are now trending again—especially on platforms like TikTok—because they often reflect natural and practical ways to stay well.

**Impact**
This discovery gives medieval medicine a much-deserved reputation makeover and offers promising ideas that could enrich how we think about health today. It also shows that looking back at history can inspire new ways to care for ourselves.

**What’s next step**
Researchers plan to continue exploring these old health practices to better understand their effectiveness and possibly incorporate some into modern medicine. They hope this work will also change how history and science are taught.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Medieval health hacks, once dismissed, are now celebrated for their natural wisdom and are inspiring today’s wellness trends.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les conseils de santé médiévaux font un retour avec une touche moderne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
De nouvelles recherches montrent une nouvelle lumière sur la médecine médiévale, montrant que les premiers Européens ne comptaient pas seulement sur la superstition. Au lieu de cela, ils ont utilisé la nature, une observation minutieuse et une expérience pratique pour développer des remèdes pour la santé, dont certains correspondent étonnamment aux conseils de bien-être populaires d'aujourd'hui.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Une équipe internationale, y compris des experts de l'Université de Binghamton, a découvert que les pratiques de santé médiévales étaient plus réfléchies et avancées que nous le croyions. Ces anciens remèdes, autrefois négligés, sont maintenant à nouveau tendance - en particulier sur des plateformes comme Tiktok - parce qu'elles reflètent souvent des moyens naturels et pratiques de rester bien.

**Impact**
Cette découverte donne à la médecine médiévale une cure de jouvence de réputation très méritée et offre des idées prometteuses qui pourraient enrichir notre façon de penser la santé aujourd'hui. Cela montre également que regarder en arrière l'histoire peut inspirer de nouvelles façons de s'occuper de nous-mêmes.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient de continuer à explorer ces anciennes pratiques de santé pour mieux comprendre leur efficacité et éventuellement en intégrer certains dans la médecine moderne. Ils espèrent que ce travail changera également la façon dont l'histoire et la science sont enseignées.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Les hacks de santé médiévaux, une fois rejetés, sont désormais célébrés pour leur sagesse naturelle et inspirent les tendances du bien-être d'aujourd'hui.
articles.personality_title_es: Los consejos de salud medieval regresan con un toque moderno
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Una nueva investigación brilla una nueva luz sobre la medicina medieval, que muestra que los primeros europeos no solo dependían de la superstición. En cambio, usaron la naturaleza, la observación cuidadosa y la experiencia práctica para desarrollar remedios de salud, algunos de los cuales sorprendentemente coinciden con los consejos de bienestar populares de hoy.

**Qué pasó**
Un equipo internacional, incluidos expertos de la Universidad de Binghamton, descubrió que las prácticas de salud medieval eran más atenta y avanzada de lo que solíamos creer. Estos remedios antiguos, una vez pasados por alto, ahora están en tendencia nuevamente, especialmente en plataformas como Tiktok, porque a menudo reflejan formas naturales y prácticas de mantenerse bien.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento le da a la medicina medieval un cambio de reputación muy merecido y ofrece ideas prometedoras que podrían enriquecer cómo pensamos en la salud hoy. También muestra que mirar hacia atrás en la historia puede inspirar nuevas formas de cuidarnos a nosotros mismos.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Los investigadores planean continuar explorando estas viejas prácticas de salud para comprender mejor su efectividad y posiblemente incorporar algunos en la medicina moderna. Esperan que este trabajo también cambie la forma en que se enseñan la historia y la ciencia.

**Control de una oración**
Los hacks de salud medieval, una vez despedidos, ahora se celebran por su sabiduría natural e inspiran las tendencias de bienestar actual.
